'White people shoot at us': Southern Brazil's Indigenous communities fight for ancestral land
description: In Mato Grosso do Sul, a southern state bordering Paraguay, Indigenous people who tried to reclaim the lands from which they had been dispossessed face violence from large landowners. The left-wing government largely remains powerless in the face of this tragedy.

headline: Trump imposes 50% tariffs on Brazil, citing trial of ally Bolsonaro
Ukraine to 'fix' anti-graft law, says foreign minister ahead of vote
Journalists in the West Bank face mounting suppression
description: Since October 7, Israel has arrested and imprisoned at least 140 journalists working in this occupied territory, most often under the catch-all charge of 'incitement to terrorism.' The Palestinian Journalists Syndicate has condemned what it describes as a strategy to 'silence' media professionals.

headline: Millions return home as Pacific tsunami warnings lifted
description: Storm surges of up to four meters (12 feet) were predicted for some parts of the Pacific, after the 8.8 quake struck off Russia's Kamchatka peninsula. The US Geological Survey said the quake was one of the 10 strongest tremors recorded since 1900. It was followed by dozens of aftershocks that further shook the Russian Far East

headline: Mount Etna: Sicily's protective, thunderous mother
description: 'Of Volcanoes and Men' (1/6). Volcanoes sow death when they erupt and give life through their fertile soil, inspiring fear and fascination. Between 2018 and 2023, Sicilian photographer Emanuele Occhipinti spent long months on the slopes of Mount Etna. Beyond the majestic landscapes, his images reveal the daily life of villagers living near this unpredictable 'mother,' toward whom they feel a love mixed with apprehension.

headline: Gabriel Hagaï, a mystic and political rabbi
description: Hagaï, 57, has lived a thousand lives. A specialist in Hebrew manuscripts, the religious figure who embraces mystical Judaism has also been a baker in Boston, a researcher and, currently, a herbalist.

'I learned freedom at 34, and it was a revelation': Katja Lange-Müller, an eastern wind blows through West Berlin
description: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (3/6). Katja Lange-Müller, born in the German Democratic Republic (GDR), managed as an adult to cross 'to the other side' of the Wall, escaping her mother, a prominent member of the communist regime.

headline: Nika Lozovska, chef: 'I work in a London restaurant called Brat. In Ukrainian, that means brother'
description: 'Refugee Recipes' (2/6). After training in Paris, Chef Nika Lozovska opened her restaurant, Dizyngoff, in the Black Sea city of Odesa in 2015. She fled the war in Ukraine and settled in London, where she keeps the memory of her hometown alive through a heirloom tomato and samphire salad.

headline: 'In the West Berlin squats, we argued but lived together': Karin Wieland, political rebel
description: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (2/6). In the late 1970s, Karin Wieland fled her small German town to live communally in an abandoned building in Kreuzberg, throwing herself into every cause of the era.
